description: From Middle English when(ne), whanne, from Old English hwonne, from Proto-West Germanic *hwannƒì, from Proto-West Germanic *hwan, from Proto-Germanic *hwan (‚Äúat what time, when‚Äù), from Proto-Indo-European *k ∑is (interrogative base).

Cognate with Dutch wanneer (‚Äúwhen‚Äù) and wen (‚Äúwhen, if‚Äù), Low German wannehr (‚Äúwhen‚Äù), wann (‚Äúwhen‚Äù) and wenn (‚Äúif, when‚Äù), German wann (‚Äúwhen‚Äù) and wenn (‚Äúwhen, if‚Äù), Gothic êçàêå∞êåΩ (∆ïan, ‚Äúwhen, how‚Äù), Latin quand≈ç (‚Äúwhen‚Äù). More at who.
Interjection sense: a playful misunderstanding of "say when" (i.e. say something / speak up when you want me to stop) as "say [the word] when".

entries.meaning: (interrogative) At what time? At which time? Upon which occasion or circumstance? Used to introduce direct or indirect questions about time.
examples: Do you know when they arrived?
I don't know when they arrived.

entries.meaning: At an earlier time and under different, usually less favorable, circumstances.
examples: He's mister high and mighty now, but I remember him when.

entries.meaning: (relative) At which, on which, during which: often omitted or replaced with that.
examples: That was the day when the Twin Towers fell.

entries.meaning: (fused relative) The time at, on or during which.
examples: I recall when they were called the Greys.
Next year is when we elect a new mayor.

entries.meaning: (informal, in definitions or explanations) A circumstance or situation in which.
examples: Love is when you can't get enough of someone.

entries.meaning: The time at which something happens.
examples: A good article will cover the who, the what, the when, the where, the why and the how.
